item.title: Coronavirus: Consumers 'should shop with confidence', says PM
item.description: Boris Johnson urges people to maintain social distancing when non-essential shops reopen in England.

item.title: Greater Manchester illegal raves: Man dies, woman raped and three stabbed
item.description: Two illegal raves attracted about 6,000 people and led to "tragic consequences".

item.title: Coronavirus: Boris Johnson launches review into 2m social distancing rule
item.description: There have been concerns the hospitality sector will struggle to be viable with the rule in place.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: New evidence 'significant' - Portuguese police
item.description: A Portuguese police source rejects criticism over their investigation into the missing three-year-old.

item.title: Swiss search for owner of gold haul left on train
item.description: The hoard, worth around £152,000, was found left behind on a train in Switzerland last October.

item.title: Harlow 'drive-by' shooting: Man in 50s dies
item.description: The victim, in his 50s, one of three hurt in the gun attack after a party in Harlow, Essex.

item.title: Man arrested over urinating at PC Keith Palmer memorial
item.description: The Met Police said officers had arrested a man on suspicion of outraging public decency.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Scandal' BAME review recommendations 'buried'
item.description: Labour's David Lammy urged the government to "do something" to protect ethnic minorities from Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: Hampshire school ready to welcome students
item.description: Some teachers and students across England are heading back to school this week, so how are they feeling?

item.title: Gatwick drone arrests: Sussex Police pays out £200,000
item.description: Paul and Elaine Gait say they are "delighted to be vindicated" after a long fight for justice.

item.title: Bear Grylls: 'Scouts must learn from Robert Baden-Powell's failings'
item.description: Chief scout Bear Grylls says "if he were here today we would disagree with him on many things".

item.title: Sushant Singh Rajput: Bollywood actor dies at 34
item.description: The film and television actor was found dead in his apartment in the city of Mumbai, police said.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'It's very exciting to be returning to work'
item.description: Non-essential shops in England can reopen on Monday and many staff can't wait to get back to business.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your pictures on the theme of 'self-portrait'
item.description: Our readers reveal portraits of themselves they have made while at home during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: What will clothes shopping look like?
item.description: From Monday all non-essential shops are allowed to reopen in England.

item.title: Woman hatches ducks from Waitrose eggs
item.description: Beep, Peep and Meep started life on a supermarket shelf but will now live with Charli Lello's chickens.

item.title: Coronavirus: France's ancient burial brotherhood defies Covid-19
item.description: The Charitable Brothers of Saint-Eloi were founded in the 12th Century to bury plague victims.

item.title: Star Trek: Next Generation fan rebuilds bridge set
item.description: Geoff Collard, a model maker, spent 500 hours building the bridge of the starship Enterprise.

item.title: Coronavirus: How sex workers are surviving in Uganda and Nigeria
item.description: While African governments give aid to their citizens during the Covid-19 pandemic, sex workers have seemingly been forgotten.

item.title: Coronavirus: 200-year-old family shoe shop to reopen
item.description: A family business dating back eight generations has lost more than £100,000 during the lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: London bus driver on working during pandemic
item.description: British Iraqi bus driver Susan on overcoming her fears to work while coronavirus was surging across the UK.

item.title: Fact-checking claims coronavirus might have started in August 2019
item.description: Does a study suggesting possibility of coronavirus cases in Wuhan much earlier than reported stand up to scrutiny?

item.title: Secondary schools get ready to welcome back pupils
item.description: A secondary head describes her plans to bring pupils back to school and keep the virus at bay.

item.title: Growing up black in one of England's whitest counties
item.description: "The N-word was shouted at me from passing cars" - life growing up as a black child in Cornwall.

item.title: Kathy Sullivan: The woman who's made history in sea and space
item.description: Kathy Sullivan is the first person to ever travel to both space and the bottom of the ocean.

item.title: The Salisbury Poisonings: TV drama revisits Novichok attack 'horror'
item.description: A BBC mini-series about the 2018 Novichok attack is not your average spy thriller, its makers say.

item.title: Coronavirus: Island isolation over as Greece lets tourists back
item.description: The idyllic islands of Mykonos and Santorini reopen for tourists, but not everyone is happy.

item.title: My Money: 'We are £200 to £300 a month worse off'
item.description: Laura Tarver from Oxford takes us through her weekly spending during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Home and Away: How we film kissing at distance
item.description: The Australian soap is back filming and has tips for UK shows on how to film safely.

item.title: Coronavirus: Single person seeks best bubble options
item.description: New guidelines allow single-person households to create an exclusive "bubble" - but how do you choose?

item.title: 'No friendships' with Archer during Test series, says Roach
item.description: There will be "no friendships" between West Indies players and England's Jofra Archer during the forthcoming Test series, says Kemar Roach.

item.title: Real win at temporary home to mark Zidane's 200th game as boss
item.description: Real Madrid mark manager Zinedine Zidane's 200th game in charge with a 3-1 'home' win over Eibar in unfamiliar surroundings.

item.title: Monday's football gossip: Man Utd to step up £75m push for Grealish
item.description: Manchester United will step up efforts for Jack Grealish with Jadon Sancho out of reach, Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang speaks on big Arsenal decision, plus more.

item.title: Euros On This Day - 14 June: Ruthless Spain punish Republic of Ireland, Nedved sparkles and Larsson scores a stunner
item.description: BBC Sport rounds up the best archive action from 14 June in European Championship history.

item.title: Djokovic cries in front of home fans after victory
item.description: World number one Novak Djokovic is brought to tears after bowing out of his Adria Tour with victory over German Alexander Zverev in front of home fans.

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are becoming compulsory for people using public transport in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing in England aimed at helping single people cut off from family and friends.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Nine million people have accessed the scheme, which will move to its next phase in July.

item.title: Coronavirus: What shops will open next?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England from Monday, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Can I stay with my boyfriend now? And other questions
item.description: Questions about support bubbles, and other coronavirus topics

item.title: Coronavirus: Five ways shopping will be different from now on
item.description: Shops in England are preparing to welcome customers back but what will the "new normal" look like?

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: The first "support bubbles" of people who can meet indoors has been announced in England and Northern Ireland.

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is a recession?
item.description: The world faces the worst recession for 80 years. But what does that mean?

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are going back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work in England?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, bars, cafes and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Pubs and restaurants in England are expected to reopen in July, but can I meet a friend for a meal?

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: Five unanswered questions on the travel quarantine rules
item.description: Travellers to the UK now have to self-isolate for 14 days. But how will the rules work in practice?

item.title: When can I ride an e-scooter legally?
item.description: With people told to avoid public transport, the government's hoping to trial e-scooter rental schemes.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Can thermal cameras help spot coronavirus?
item.description: The devices allow a person's temperature to be checked from a distance, but are not always reliable.

item.title: Coronavirus and face coverings: the correct way to wear them
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the chance of going on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Coronavirus: Saffron Walden dentist shows new appointment routine
item.description: Join us on a walk through a dental surgery to show what you might face at your next appointment.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are protests legal amid lockdown?
item.description: Black Lives Matter protests continue in the UK - but are they illegal under restrictions on gatherings?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why are international comparisons difficult?
item.description: Should you be comparing Covid-19 statistics between countries?

item.title: Can superspreading be stopped?
item.description: Identifying superspreading events could be crucial in the fight against the virus, scientists say.

item.title: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: NHS test & trace: Does contact tracing stop coronavirus?
item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Racism in the UK: 'I feel like an alien'
item.description: Four black men speak to the BBC's Ashley John-Baptiste about their experiences of racism in daily life.

item.title: Surfing tragedy that stunned a Dutch beach community
item.description: Five young, skilled surfers were overcome by freak foam conditions in Scheveningen.

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: The great housemate sex dilemma
item.description: How will housemates choose who gets to have sex under the new rules?

item.title: Five key questions about energy after Covid-19
item.description: The pandemic has seen CO2 emissions fall - but will these changes be permanent?

item.title: Coronavirus: Should I go to university this year?
item.description: Will students have online or face-to-face learning this autumn, and will they still have to pay full fees?

item.title: A surprise lockdown apology from my ex
item.description: Have the long hours of isolation during coronavirus lockdown led people to reflect on failed relationships?
